entry.title: Gmm with R - Estimating the returns to schooling
entry.content:
In this post, I will explain how you can use the R gmm package to estimate a simple linear model. For my research, I have to estimate euler equations using the Generalized Method of Moments. I contacted Pierre Chaussé, the creator of the gmm library for help, since I was having some difficulties. I am very grateful for his help (without him, I’d still probably be trying to estimate my model!).

Theoretical background

I will not dwell in the theory too much, because you can find everything you need here. The model to be estimated can be found in Marno Verbeek’s A guide to modern Econometrics on page 137. You can download the data from the book’s companion page here under the section Data sets and then look for Chapter 5: Endogeneity, instrumental variables and GMM returns to schooling. Unfortunately the data set is not available in the .csv format, but R can read STATA data sets (using the foreign library), so you can get the .dta file.

The linear model to be estimated is the following:

[ \log(wage) = \beta_1 + \beta_2 * schooling + \beta_3 * exper + \beta_4 * exper^2 + \beta_5 * black + \beta_6 * smsa + \beta_7 * south
]

If every right hand side variables are exogeneous, the parameters of this model can be estimated using ordinary least squares. This translates to the following moment condition:

[ E[X * \varepsilon] = 0 ]

where ( X ) is the matrix of variables.
